attributes.alt: Cover for More-igami by Dori Kleber. Cover shows a boy sitting at a table working on origami.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What is one thing Joey folded in the story?
Read for enjoyment, with a focus on shapes.

Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Remove a word from a compound word.
Children understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Choose an Activity Card and give hints as to what shape is on it.
Guide children to guess the shape or ask for more information.
How can we express ourselves through making art?
What shape is your book cover?
Pretend to be an artist. What kind of art are you making?
Find a triangle. Find a square. How are they the same? How are they different?
Can you write about a shape you see? Use words and numbers.
Can you draw a triangle? Can you draw a square?
. Which letter looks like a triangle? Which looks like a circle?
Use blocks to make a square.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to discuss initiative and review familiar shapes.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Combine shapes to create a picture or design; Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.

attributes.alt: Cover for More-igami by Dori Kleber. Cover shows a boy sitting at a table working on origami.

elements.text: Guide children to create ladybug origami using the directions on pages 32–33 of
Help children describe the shapes they create.
How can we express ourselves through making art?
Tell me about the main character, the most important person or animal in your story.
What does it look like to be brave and strong?
Choose your favorite shape. Why do you like it?
Write a story with you in it. What problem do you have? How will you solve that problem?
Work with a friend to create something together.
Make a design out of your favorite letters.
Use different shapes to build a very strong tower.

attributes.alt: Cover for More-igami by Dori Kleber. Cover shows a boy sitting at a table working on origami.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss geometry, engage children with art, and introduce vocabulary
How did Joey learn to make origami?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review two- and three-dimensional shapes.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Have children pick an object from a bag.
Ask children to describe the object and sort it by whether it is flat or not.
Discuss the properties of two- and three-dimensional shapes.
How can we express ourselves through making art?
Where do you see shapes in this book?
Pretend to climb the side of a very big pyramid!
How is a pyramid like a triangle? How is it different?
Write about what kind of art you like best.
Can you make a not-flat shape like a box or a ball?
Write your name. Do you see any shapes in your name? Which shapes?

attributes.alt: Cover for More-igami by Dori Kleber. Cover shows a boy sitting at a table working on origami.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about different genres of art, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to classification by sorting types of artwork.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Combine shapes to create a picture or design; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences; Collect, organize, and present data graphically.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Experiment with a variety of small-motor tasks.
Ask children to sculpt anything they like using modeling clay.
Guide children to sort their creations into categories.
Help children create a bar graph.
How can we express ourselves through making art?
Choose two pictures in the book. Which one do you like better? Why?
Pretend to be a sculptor. What will you make?
Use Pattern Blocks to make a horse or another animal.
Write about two kinds of art you would like to try making.
What tools do you like to use best when you are drawing a picture? Why?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
Can you build a horse and a fence that is taller than the horse?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice making a rectangle and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the Big Book and asking,
What can you do to become a master of something?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on geometry.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What is your favorite way to create art?
Save children’s responses to display next week.
How can we express ourselves through making art?
Find a book illustration that you love. Tell a friend why you love it.
Pretend to display your best art in a museum. Describe your creation to a friend.
What art can you make from materials in this center?
Write about a child who loves making art.
What does your artwork tell people about yourself?
Use foam letters to create a work of art. Which letters did you use?
Choose three shapes that you like. Can you make a building out of those shapes?
